segments.text: At the present time, the total protein, the ocean is primarily a source of food protein, either for, in terms of food, not the total resources of the ocean, in terms of both food for human beings, fish that people like to eat and seek, invertebrates people like to eat,
and food for animals, fish meal, fish flour.
Fish meals are fed to chicken and to livestock.
And the total protein supply that we get this way in terms of human food is of the order of 12 million tons a year.
12 to 15 million tons a year of protein.
If you divide that by the number of people on Earth, how does that look?
Let me just do it.
Just any place might be full.
Say we have 12 times 10 to the sixth ton.
divided by 4 times 10 to the 9 people equals 3 times 10 to the minus third tons per person equals 3 kilograms per person per year.
Well, the total program, the total protein requirement per person is about
50 times 365 equals about 18 kiloamps.
So that for the world as a whole, we're providing about
The protein requirement we're providing, the ocean provides three eight-teens, with one six, about 15, it's about, six is about 17% as opposed to the world protein, human protein.
It's actually less than the world protein consumption, but because
Americans and Europeans and Japanese eat a lot more protein.
But anyhow, this is what people require.
Well, it's not really a major factor in human protein supply.
And it's probably true that we can't get more than 100 million tons of fish out of the ocean by the present fishing techniques.
We've exploited all resources intelligently.
very effectively.
Moreover, this would be quite an expensive way to get protein.
Deep sea fishing is an energy-intensive business.
It uses a lot of energy.
So I think that, in general, the notion that the ocean is a great reservoir of protein is, with the present fishing techniques, is just not so.
our great reservoir of food supply.
Of course, food, we need millions of it.

We need something like the total requirement right now is something like a billion, 200 million, 300 million, about a billion and a half million, a billion, 500 million tons of food, mostly for calories.
But by the development of
of ocean farming, we might be able to increase this production of things that people like and need maybe several fold over.
And the interesting thing about ocean farming is that you do it in a different way than you do it on land.
The best example is the mussel farming that the Spaniards do.
They get about 100 tons to the acre of mussels
maybe 20 tons to the acre of protein, which is fantastically high.
The reason that they're able to do this is that they put their muscles on ropes or pilings, but mostly ropes, I think, in an area where the current constantly sweeps by them.
So that the ocean is fertilizing itself.
You're taking advantage of the organic production in a large part of the ocean.
sweeping by these mussels, and the mussels all you do is just filter it out of the water as it goes by.
That's why you get these high yields.
And that's the way to do marine farming, I think, not to take a piece of ocean and fertilize it.
Might as well just use ordinary agriculture for that.
But to take advantage of the oceans, of the motions of the ocean, to make the ocean fertilize itself, and to bring nutrients to a small area.
from which you then get a large crop.
And I think that the energy requirements here are rather low.
The energy requirements are primarily catching and handling, not so much energy for fertilizer or energy for plowing or energy for pumping water.
the ocean will do all that for you.
You have to catch the mussels.
You have to hang them there.
You have to pull them up and take them out of their shells and then do something with them.
I would think particularly of mariculture of organisms like mussels, oysters, clams, and mussels, which are filter feeders.
therefore can collect are just essentially little plankton nets, convert the plankton into something we like to eat, seafood.
Plankton is impossible to eat for a variety of reasons, one being it has a lot of silicon.
And I wouldn't be surprised if this were done on a
If we learned how to do this and did it on a large scale, we couldn't double the protein production of the ocean.
There should be a significant step in the right direction.
Still not.
Still, it would probably be only 20% or 25% of the total human protein, world population protein requirements.
I don't see how the world population could possibly be stabilized below 10 or 12 billion people.
Well, so much for mariculture.
I had another question I was going to ask you before we got on mariculture.
It has to do with modifying the climate on the Earth.
You had mentioned twice ecology.
Do you think we can safely experiment, as a matter of fact, with modifying the climate on the Earth?
Well, we're doing it.
We can't do the paperwork, though.
You were going to come back and report to me.
Oh, I forgot.
I was wondering if you'd like a little snack for lunch.
It's getting on toward that time.
I don't have any honey, and I don't have any avocado to make you a honey avocado.
Let me move your coffee pot over here.
Yes, I would very much.
Thank you.
I think we can wind this thing up for you in a few minutes here.
What was your question again?
I was talking about modifying it twice or three times in our conversation.
Something's come up with the idea of the ecology system and modifying the climate.
We are modifying it.
We probably are modifying the climate.
That is almost certain.
By adding carbon dioxide to the atmosphere.
And we're adding a lot.
We're adding now.
About a half of 1% of the, every year, we're adding a half of 1% of the atmospheric carbon dioxide to the atmosphere.
We're pretty close to that.
And this is something that we don't want to do.
We're just doing it by burning fossil fuels.
And the real question is, what's going to happen?
It's a great geophysical experiment in one way.
It's also maybe a great concern to human beings.
Now, the ocean enters into this in a profound way.
We're actually burning fossil fuels about carbon dioxide production is about 1% of the atmospheric carbon dioxide every year, going up to 3% or 4% maybe in 100 years if we keep on burning coal.
But about half of this at the present time goes into the ocean.
What do you think?
An unknown proportion goes into the biosphere, and maybe not any goes into the biosphere, but maybe a significant amount.
The land biosphere, I think.
The reason that we're able to absorb half of it in the ocean is that the ocean has something called a bucker mechanism of seawater.
That is, there are carbonate ions in the ocean which have two negative charges that can be turned into bicarbonate if you add CO2.
Bicarbonate has only one negative charge.
As long as the carbonate ion is present, the ocean can absorb CO2 by transforming the carbonate into bicarbonate.
However, it looks as if, as time goes on, we're going to use up the carbonate ion in the ocean, and therefore the ocean won't be able to absorb very much CO2.
Most of it will stay in the atmosphere.
So that will make the situation worse than it is now.
Moreover, if we do this, we're going to heat up the surface waters of the ocean because the atmosphere will get warm again.
And they won't be able to hold so much carbonic acid gas.
So more carbon dioxide will get into the air from the ocean, because the ocean will be losing it.
Moreover, as the atmosphere heats up and as the ocean surface layer heats up, there will be more evaporation and more cloud formation.
This may be a countervailing effect.

Nobody really knows what the effect will be, whether it will increase the albedo of the earth, that is, the reflectivity, so we get less incoming radiation, or whether it will, in fact, increase the temperature in order to get, because clouds radiate infrared at a lower temperature than the ground surface does, you may therefore have to raise the temperature in order to get enough radiation out to maintain a heat balance.
I'm quite uncertain what's going to happen.
All the climatic models are fatally weak because they're unable to model the ocean.
And they're unable to modify the cloud formation of the ocean.
You have to learn how to do this.
And this will be, I think, a combination of observation and theory.
It can't be done by either one alone.
You observe cloud formation over the ocean.
You observe the albedo of the clouds and their infrared radiation and see what happens in different areas under the variations we now get.
And from this, develop a better theory of cloud formation and a better theory of the interaction between the sea and the air.
One thing that's characteristic of the ocean is that it carries about half the heat.
from low latitudes to high latitudes.
The other half is carried in the air.
Nobody knows whether it's 40% or 50% or 60%.
That makes a lot of difference in models, not in space models.
Present climatological models assume one of two things about the ocean.
Either that the ocean is a swamp from which water can evaporate but no heat can be absorbed because it's such a thin layer of water, or that it's got an infinite heat capacity.
Neither of which is true.
The truth is somewhere in between.
And the models just can't take account of that.
I don't think you're going to be able to get very much further to it unless you have a lot more studies of the interaction between the sea and the air.
Rather than talk about climate modification, I'd like to talk about climate and what's going to happen to it.
And the only thing we can say with any certainty now about climate is that the climate fluctuates.
Sometimes it's one way, and sometimes it's another.
And we know that it always has fluctuated.
The longer the period of observation, the greater the fluctuation.
That's characteristic of what are called stochastic processes.
And it's very likely that the climate's going to get worse.
It's no more likely that the climate will get better, but it's equally likely that it will get worse.
It's going to vary somehow.
And we have to be prudent and to act as if we're going to get worse, even though it may not.
That means we have to do a lot of things about agriculture.
But in order to know what to do about agriculture, we have to know what's going to happen.
If the climate does get worse, what does that mean?
Horse latitudes shift north or south.
Does it mean you get more or less precipitation?
Does it mean the pattern of precipitation changes?
Does it mean that the temperature patterns change?
And if so, in what way are they going to change?
Climatology at the present time is a very primitive science.
And half of climatology is oceanography.
But the Global Atmospheric Research Program, which involves oceanography as well as meteorology,
that it's just a very important thing to be doing from a purely practical point of view, let alone from a theoretical and scientifically interesting point of view.
But, you know, the notion that you dam up the Bering Sea or run the Amur River into the Arctic or something like that, these are all trivial problems compared to the real problem.
What's going to happen to the climate without our doing a goddamn thing?
Except putting CO2 into it.
on a very large scale?
Do we have to abandon carbon dioxide in production?
Do we have to abandon the use of fossil fuels because we're going to change the climate so drastically by continuing to use them?
Or can we continue to use them and prepare for what changes will occur?
That leads directly in effect to another question I have.
The one thing that strikes me as consistent in your career, if I may use that word, or consistently apparent in your career, is the scientist as public man.
Do you have any particular philosophical views about what the scientist's responsibility is to the public?
Well, personally, he has the same responsibility as everybody else.
He's a good citizen.
But he also has special responsibilities.
because he either knows something that other people don't know, or because he has ways of finding out things that other people don't know about.
And I think that the scientist has maybe two responsibilities.
One is to be an entertainer, to be, like other artists,
give people pleasure and happiness.
And this is particularly obvious with astronomy.
People really are fascinated by astronomy.
And it has some very deep meaning to people, which is hard to describe.
But you can see it when you look at an audience being talked to by an astronomer or by somebody who talks about astronomy.
They often have tears in their eyes.
overwhelmingly emotionally involved in it.
And that's the entertainment aspect of science.

Seafloor spreading, plate tectonics, whether there's light on Mars, what's the history of the Earth, what's the history of living creatures, what's the diversity of living creatures, all their peculiar and funny ways and interesting ways.
Let's leave that tentative curtain that we see out there in front of us.
These are all kind of things that Cousteau does and that many people do.
These are very important aspects of the scientist's responsibility to the public.
After all, the public's paying for what he does.
They ought to get something out of it.
The other thing, of course, is that the scientist has
the responsibility of laying the basis for a humane technology, a technology which serves the interests of people and doesn't disserve the interests of people.
The technologists themselves have a major responsibility here, but most modern technology is based on science,
knowledge of nature and knowledge of ourselves and knowledge of other living creatures, biological knowledge, scientific knowledge of living things and of the inanimate world.
So I think one of the responsibilities of the scientists was to try to
consider and talk about and think about, or to consider, think about, and talk about, put them in that order, what are the likely consequences of increasing, of increases in scientific knowledge?
And to do that in such a way that you don't scare people, but you give them a chance to make intelligent choices and intelligent decisions.
You can't make the decisions for them, but you can give them the knowledge by which they can make better decisions.
And then the final thing is to do good science.
That's a responsibility, too, because science is a human activity of, how to put it,
Science is something that people can do.
Finding out about the world and about ourselves is an important human activity, something that makes people human.
It gives them a higher humanity and a more intense experience.
Most scientists, of course, feel this very strongly.
I think they're right that it's one of the wonderful things about human beings that they can understand nature, up to a point at least.
And we haven't reached that limit yet.
I don't want to just put you ahead as fast as we can to find out as much as we can.
Maybe we will find eventually one of two things will happen, that science becomes so complicated
If it loses its unity and its integrity, therefore people won't be interested in it.
No, it's not necessary.
I mean, it's quite possible that we could develop a civilization that couldn't care less about knowing about nature.
Alternatively, the possibility is it will come up against barriers in our minds or limitations of our own minds and our own ability to understand.
That isn't in sight yet, but it may be within the next 100 years.
I guess that science is, you can think of science sort of like you think about population.
It can't go on forever.
The rate at which we're learning things is accelerating.
That leads to a discontinuity of something.
An exponential curve is by
fundamentally an unstable, leads to a discontinuity.
So it can't go on exponentially.
In other words, maybe we'll go like this and level off like that.
Maybe we'll go like this and go like that.
One of those two things might happen.
Now, I have one final question, and you're long
Gosh, I think that's an impossible question to answer.
You'd have to ask me that 50 years after I'm dead.
I guess the thing that I feel proudest of
It's not saying it's most important, but one that I feel was a high point of my life was starting the University of California in San Diego.
You know, that may not turn out very well after all.
Something else may happen, more important.
But so far, I think it's turned out pretty well.
I mean, that was a great experience, and an experience that very few people have.
It couldn't have happened at any other time
In history, just like it happened, technology and science were riding high.
There was plenty of money.
People thought there were going to be a lot of people in California.
Everything fitted together.
We were just awfully lucky.
But we didn't.
Because we were lucky, we managed to do something that was, in some sense, unique.
